title: 107_hr1127
content: The "Health Care Tax Deduction Act of 2001" is introduced, creating a deduction for health insurance and prescription drug costs for individuals under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Care Tax Deduction Act of 2001" allows individuals to deduct insurance and prescription drug expenses for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Employer contributions to certain accounts are also considered as paid by the employer. The "Health Care Tax Deduction Act of 2001" allows individuals to deduct insurance and prescription drug expenses for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Deductions are not available for ancillary coverage premiums such as accidents, disability, dental care, vision care, or specified illness. Coordination with other deductions for self-employed individuals and medical expenses is also specified. The "Health Care Tax Deduction Act of 2001" allows deductions for insurance and prescription drug expenses, excluding certain types of insurance. Medical care is defined according to section 213(d), with exceptions for long-term care insurance contracts and certain other insurance benefits. The "Health Care Tax Deduction Act of 2001" allows deductions for unreimbursed prescription drug expenses, defined as costs not reimbursed by insurance. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for implementation. The deduction is allowed regardless of whether the taxpayer itemizes other deductions. The "Health Care Tax Deduction Act of 2001" allows deductions for health insurance and prescription drug costs for self-employed individuals starting after December 31, 2001. The "Health Care Tax Deduction Act of 2001" allows self-employed individuals to deduct 100 percent of medical insurance costs and unreimbursed prescription drug expenses for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The "Health Care Tax Deduction Act of 2001" allows self-employed individuals to deduct medical insurance costs and prescription drug expenses for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The amendments made by this section clarify limitations on other coverage and include a clerical amendment to the heading for section 162(l) of the Code. Effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
